fields.name: activities
fields.description:
Get user activities.

### OAuth Scopes

The following scopes will need to be present on OAuth requests to get data from this field

* __confluence:atlassian-external__
* __jira:atlassian-external__

fields.name: appActiveTunnels
fields.description:
Returns the list of active tunnels for a given app-id and environment-key.

The tunnels are active for 30min by default, if not requested to be terminated.

fields.name: appHostServices
fields.description: Returns information about all the scopes from different Atlassian products

fields.name: appLogLines
fields.description:
`appLogLines()` returns an object for paging over the contents of a single
invocation's log lines, given by the `invocation` parameter (an ID
returned from a `appLogs()` query).

Each `AppLogLine` consists of a `timestamp`, an optional `message`,
an optional `level`, and an `other` field that contains any
additional JSON fields included in the log line.  (Since
the app itself can control the schema of this JSON, we can't
use native GraphQL capabilities to describe the fields here.)

The returned objects use the Relay naming/nesting style of
`AppLogLineConnection` → `[AppLogLineEdge]` →  `AppLogLine`.

args.name: invocation
args.description: The `id` returned from an appLog() query.

fields.name: appLogs
fields.description:
`appLogs()` returns an object for paging over AppLog objects, each of which
represents one invocation of a function.

The returned objects use the Relay naming/nesting style of
`AppLogConnection` → `[AppLogEdge]` →  `AppLog`.

It takes parameters (`query: LogQueryInput`) to narrow down the invocations
being searched, requiring at least an app and environment.

args.name: appId
args.description: The app ID. Required.

args.name: environmentId
args.description:
Specify which environment(s) to search.
Must not be empty if you want any results.

fields.name: bitbucketRepositoriesAvailableToLinkWithNewDevOpsService

If nameFilter is provided, only repositories with names containing this case-insensitive string will be returned.
With an existing service, the caller should use `devOpsService.bitbucketRepositoriesAvailableToLinkWith` field.

fields.name: search
fields.description:
The search method serves as an entry point to the various results across multiple Atlassian products.
This method proxy to Search Platform's API xpsearch-aggregator.
It supports multi tenant search with product specific filtering.

fields.name: tenantContexts
fields.description:
A Jira or Confluence cloud instance, such as `hello.atlassian.net` has a backing
cloud ID such as `0ee6b491-5425-4f19-a71e-2486784ad694`

This field allows you to look up the cloud IDs or host names of tenanted applications
such as Jira or Confluence.

You MUST provide a list of cloud IDs or a list of host names to look up but not both
otherwise an error will be returned

fields.name: testing
fields.description:
This field is useful for testing the graphql API.  In fact here at Atlassian we run synthetic checks
using this field ot help us ensure the graphql API is working as expected.

fields.name: user
fields.description:
Given an account id this will return user profile information with applied privacy controls of the caller.

Its important to remember that privacy controls are applied in terms of the caller.  A user with
a certain accountId may exist but the current caller may not have the right to view their details.

fields.name: users
fields.description:
Given a list of account ids this will return user profile information with applied privacy controls of the caller.

Its important to remember that privacy controls are applied in terms of the caller.  A user with
a certain accountId may exist but the current caller may not have the right to view their details.

A maximum of 90 `accountIds` can be asked for at the one time.

types.name: ID
types.description: The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: Int
types.description: The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. Int can represent values between -(2^31) and 2^31 - 1.

fields.name: id

types.name: Node
types.description:
From the [relay Node specification](https://relay.dev/graphql/objectidentification.htm#sec-Node-Interface)

The server must provide an interface called `Node`. That interface must include exactly one field, called `id` that returns a non-null `ID`.

This `id` should be a globally unique identifier for this object, and given just this `id`, the server should be able to refetch the object.

types.name: User
types.description:
There are 3 types of accounts :

* AtlassianAccountUser
* this represents a real person that has an account in a wide range of Atlassian products

* CustomerUser
* This represents a real person who is a customer of an organisation who uses an Atlassian product to provide service to their customers.
Currently, this isused within Jira Service Desk for external service desks.

* AppUser
* this does not represent a real person but rather the identity that backs an installed application

fields.name: accountId
fields.description: The account ID for the user.

fields.name: accountStatus
fields.description: The lifecycle status of the account

fields.name: name
fields.description:
The display name of the user. This should be used when rendering a user textually within content.
If the user has restricted visibility of their name, their nickname will be
displayed as a substitute value.

fields.name: picture
fields.description:
The absolute URI (RFC3986) to the avatar name of the user. This should be used when rendering a user graphically within content.
If the user has restricted visibility of their avatar or has not set
an avatar, an alternative URI will be provided as a substitute value.

types.name: AppEnvironmentVersion
types.description:
Represents a major version of an AppEnvironment.
A major version is one that requires consent from end users before upgrading installations, typically a change in
the permissions an App requires.
Other changes do not trigger a new major version to be created and are instead applied to the latest major version

fields.name: isLatest
fields.description: a flag which if true indicates this version is the latest major version for this environment

types.name: PageInfo
types.description:
Relay-style PageInfo type.

See [PageInfo specification](https://relay.dev/assets/files/connections-932f4f2cdffd79724ac76373deb30dc8.htm#sec-undefined.PageInfo)

fields.name: endCursor
fields.description: endCursor must be the cursor corresponding to the last node in `edges`.

fields.name: hasNextPage
fields.description:
`hasNextPage` is used to indicate whether more edges exist following the set defined by the clients arguments. If the client is paginating
with `first` / `after`, then the server must return true if further edges exist, otherwise false. If the client is paginating with `last` / `before`,
then the client may return true if edges further from before exist, if it can do so efficiently, otherwise may return false.

fields.name: hasPreviousPage
fields.description:
`hasPreviousPage` is used to indicate whether more edges exist prior to the set defined by the clients arguments. If the client is paginating
with `last` / `before`, then the server must return true if prior edges exist, otherwise false. If the client is paginating with `first` / `after`,
then the client may return true if edges prior to after exist, if it can do so efficiently, otherwise may return false.

fields.name: startCursor
fields.description: startCursor must be the cursor corresponding to the first node in `edges`.

fields.description:
We really don't know what other fields may be in the logs.

This field may be an array or an object.

If it's an object, it will include only fields in `includeFields`,
unless `includeFields` is null, in which case it will include
all fields that are not in `excludeFields`.

If it's an array it will include the entire array.

inputFields.description:
Limits the search to a particular date range.

Note: Logs may have a TTL on them so older logs may not be available
despite search parameters.

Limits the search to a particular function in the app.
Optional: if empty will search all functions.

inputFields.name: installationContexts

Specify which installations you want to search.
Optional: if empty will search all installations user has access to.

The start time of the earliest invocation to include in the results.
If null, search results will only be limited by retention limits.

RFC-3339 formatted timestamp.

inputFields.name: latestStart
inputFields.description:
The start time of the latest invocation to include in the results.
If null, will include most recent invocations.

RFC-3339 formatted timestamp.

inputFields.name: cloudId
inputFields.description: The identifier that indicates which cloud instance this data is to be fetched for.

inputFields.name: endAtExclusive
inputFields.description: The end dateTime for overall time interval to return results for. The interval is exclusive of this value.

inputFields.description: Issue level filters. Currently, in order to apply this filter, jiraProjectIds must also be provided

inputFields.description: List of Jira projectIds in the given 'cloudId' to fetch metrics for. Max limit of 10.

inputFields.name: resolution
inputFields.description:
The size of time interval in which to rollup data points in. Default is 1 day.
E.g. Count of data over 2 weeks with 1 day resolution means rollup is number of datapoints per day over 2 weeks.

inputFields.name: startFromInclusive
inputFields.description: The start dateTime for overall time interval to return results for. The interval is inclusive of this value.

inputFields.name: timezoneId
inputFields.description:
The Olson Timezone ID. E.g. 'Australia/Sydney'.
Specifies which timezone to aggregate data in so that daylight savings is taken into account if it occurred between request time range.

inputFields.name: epicIds
inputFields.description:
Only issues in these epics will be returned.

Note:
* If a null ID is included in the list, issues not in epics will be included in the results.
* If a subtask's parent issue is in one of the epics, the subtask will also be returned.

inputFields.name: issueTypeIds
inputFields.description: Only issues of these types will be returned.

inputFields.name: unit
inputFields.description: Input unit for specified resolution value.

inputFields.name: value
inputFields.description: Input value for resolution specified.

fields.name: hasPermissionForAllContributingIssues
fields.description: Indicates whether user requesting metrics has permission to all contributing issues.

fields.name: phase
fields.description: The development phase which the cycle time is calculated for.

fields.name: resolution
fields.description:
The size of time interval in which data points are rolled up in.
E.g. Count of data over 2 weeks with 1 day resolution means rollup is number of datapoints per day over 2 weeks.

fields.name: aggregateData
fields.description: Data aggregated according to the rollup type specified. Rounded to the nearest second.

fields.name: data
fields.description: The cycle time data points, computed using roll up of the type specified in 'metric'. Rolled up by specified resolution.

fields.name: cycleTimeSeconds
fields.description: Rolled up cycle time data (in seconds) between ('dateTime') and ('dateTime' + 'resolution'). Roll up method specified by 'metric'.

fields.name: dateTime
fields.description: dataTime of data point. Each data point is separated by size of time resolution specified.

fields.name: issuesShippedCount

fields.name: deploymentSize
fields.description:
Currently the only size metric supported is "number of issues per deployment".

Note: The issues per deployment count will ignore Jira permissions, meaning the user may not have permission to view all of the issues.
The list of `issueIds` contained in the `DeploymentSummary` will however respect Jira permissions.

types.name: DeploymentSummary
types.description:
This object models a deployment in the Continuous Delivery (CD) Pipeline concept, an automated process (usually comprised of
multiple stages) for getting software from version control right through to the production environment.

fields.name: deploymentSequenceNumber
fields.description:
This is the identifier for the deployment.

It must be unique for the specified pipeline and environment. It must be a monotonically
increasing number, as this is used to sequence the deployments.

fields.name: description
fields.description: A short description of the deployment.

fields.name: displayName
fields.description: The human-readable name for the deployment. Will be shown in the UI.

fields.name: environment
fields.description: The environment that the deployment is present in.

fields.name: issueIds
fields.description:
IDs of the issues that are included in the deployment.

At least one of the commits in the deployment must be associated with an issue for it
to appear here (meaning the issue key is mentioned in the commit message).

fields.name: lastUpdated
fields.description: The last-updated timestamp to present to the user as a summary of the state of the deployment.

fields.name: pipeline
fields.description:
This object models the Continuous Delivery (CD) Pipeline concept, an automated process
(usually comprised of multiple stages) for getting software from version control right through
to the production environment.

fields.name: provider
fields.description:
This is the DevOps provider for the deployment.

### Beta Field

This field is currently in a beta phase and may change without notice.  

To use this field you must set a `X-ExperimentalApi: DevOpsProvider` HTTP header.

Use of this header indicates that they are opting into the experimental preview of this field.

If you do not set this header then request will be rejected outright.

Once the field moves out of the beta phase, then the header will no longer be required or checked.

fields.name: serviceAssociations
fields.description:
Services associated with the deployment.

At least one of the commits in the deployment must be associated with a service ID for it
to appear here.

fields.name: state
fields.description: The state of the deployment.

fields.name: updateSequenceNumber
fields.description:
A number used to apply an order to the updates to the deployment, as identified by the
`deploymentSequenceNumber`, in the case of out-of-order receipt of update requests.

It must be a monotonically increasing number. For example, epoch time could be one
way to generate the `updateSequenceNumber`.

fields.name: url
fields.description: A URL users can use to link to this deployment, in this environment.

types.name: DevOpsEnvironment
types.description:
An environment that a code change can be released to.

The release may be via a code deployment or via a feature flag change.

fields.name: category
fields.description: The type of the environment.

fields.name: displayName
fields.description: The name of the environment to present to the user.

types.description:
This object models the Continuous Delivery (CD) Pipeline concept, an automated process (usually comprised of multiple stages)
for getting software from version control right through to the production environment.

fields.name: displayName

fields.name: danglingPullRequests
fields.description:
There are common cases where a Pull Request is merged and its branch is deleted.
The downstream sources do not provide repository information on the PR, only branches information.
When the branch is deleted, it's not possible to create the bridge between PRs and Repository.
For this reason, any PR that couldn't be assigned to a repository will appear on this list.

fields.name: devStatusErrorMessage
fields.description:
An error message related to this instance passed down from DevStatus
These are not GraphQL errors. When an instance type is requested,
DevStatus may respond with a list instances and strings nested inside the 'errors' field, as follows:
`{ 'errors': [{'_instance': { ... }, error: 'unauthorized' }], detail: [ ... ] }`.
The status code for this response however is still 200
since only part of the instances requested may present these issues.
`devStatusErrorMessage` is deprecated. Use `devStatusErrorMessages`.

fields.name: applicationPropertiesByKey
fields.description:
Retrieves application properties for the given instance.

Returns an array containing application properties for each of the provided keys. If a matching application property
cannot be found, then no entry is added to the array for that key.

A maximum of 50 keys can be provided. If the limit is exceeded then then an error may be returned.

This field is currently in a beta phase and may change without notice.  

To use this field you must set a `X-ExperimentalApi: JiraApplicationProperties` HTTP header.

Use of this header indicates that they are opting into the experimental preview of this field.

If you do not set this header then request will be rejected outright.

Once the field moves out of the beta phase, then the header will no longer be required or checked.

Use of this header indicates that they are opting into the experimental preview of this field.

If you do not set this header then request will be rejected outright.

Once the field moves out of the beta phase, then the header will no longer be required or checked.

types.name: JiraGrantTypeKey
types.description: The unique key of the grant type such as PROJECT_ROLE.

fields.name: key
fields.description: The key to identify the grant type such as PROJECT_ROLE.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The display name of the grant type key such as Project Role.

types.name: JiraGrantTypeKeyEnum
types.description:
The grant type key enum represents all the possible grant types available in Jira.
A grant type may take an optional parameter value.
For example: PROJECT_ROLE grant type takes project role id as parameter. And, PROJECT_LEAD grant type do not.

The actual ARI formats are documented on the various concrete grant type values.

enumValues.name: ANONYMOUS_ACCESS
enumValues.description:
The anonymous access represents the public access without logging in.
It takes no parameter.

enumValues.name: ANY_LOGGEDIN_USER_APPLICATION_ROLE
enumValues.description:
Any user who has the product access.
It takes no parameter.

enumValues.name: APPLICATION_ROLE
enumValues.description:
A application role is used to grant a user/group access to the application group.
It takes application role as parameter.

enumValues.name: ASSIGNEE
enumValues.description:
The issue assignee role.
It takes platform defined 'assignee' as parameter to represent the issue field value.

enumValues.name: GROUP
enumValues.description:
A group is a collection of users who can be given access together.
It represents group in the organization's user base.
It takes group id as parameter.

enumValues.name: MULTI_GROUP_PICKER
enumValues.description:
A multi group picker custom field.
It takes multi group picker custom field id as parameter.

enumValues.name: MULTI_USER_PICKER
enumValues.description:
A multi user picker custom field.
It takes multi user picker custom field id as parameter.

enumValues.name: PROJECT_LEAD
enumValues.description:
The project lead role.
It takes no parameter.

enumValues.name: PROJECT_ROLE
enumValues.description:
A role that user/group can play in a project.
It takes project role as parameter.

enumValues.name: REPORTER
enumValues.description:
The issue reporter role.
It takes platform defined 'reporter' as parameter to represent the issue field value.

enumValues.name: SERVICE_PROJECT_CUSTOMER_PORTAL_ACCESS
enumValues.description:
The grant type defines what the customers can do from the portal view.
It takes no parameter.

enumValues.name: USER
enumValues.description:
An individual user who can be given the access to work on one or more projects.
It takes user account id as parameter.

types.name: JiraApplicationProperty
types.description:
Jira application properties is effectively a key/value store scoped to a Jira instance. A JiraApplicationProperty
represents one of these key/value pairs, along with associated metadata about the property.

fields.name: allowedValues
fields.description:
If the type is 'enum', then allowedValues may optionally contain a list of values which are valid for this property.
Otherwise the value will be null.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description:
The default value which will be returned if there is no value stored. This might be useful for UIs which allow a
user to 'reset' an application property to the default value.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The human readable description for the application property

fields.name: example
fields.description:
Example is mostly used for application properties which store some sort of format pattern (e.g. date formats).
Example will contain an example string formatted according to the format stored in the property.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Globally unique identifier

fields.name: isEditable
fields.description: True if the user is allowed to edit the property, false otherwise

fields.name: key
fields.description: The unique key of the application property

fields.name: name
fields.description:
The human readable name for the application property. If no human readable name has been defined then the key will
be returned.

fields.name: type
fields.description:
Although all application properties are stored as strings, they notionally have a type (e.g. boolean, int, enum,
string). The type can be anything (for example, there is even a colour type), and there may be associated validation
on the server based on the property's type.

fields.name: value
fields.description:
The value of the application property, encoded as a string. If no value is stored the default value will
be returned.

PROJECT_LEAD ari - ari:cloud:jira:a2520569-493f-45bc-807b-54b02bc724d1:role/project-lead/activation/bd0c43a9-a23a-4302-8ffa-ca04bde7c747/project/f67c73a8-545e-455b-a6bd-3d53cb7e0524
APPLICATION_ROLE ari for JSM - ari:cloud:jira-servicedesk::role/123
ANY_LOGGEDIN_USER_APPLICATION_ROLE ari - ari:cloud:jira::role/product/member
ANONYMOUS_ACCESS ari - ari:cloud:identity::user/unidentified

fields.name: attachments
fields.description:
Paginated list of attachments available on this issue.
The server may throw an error if both a forward page (specified with `first`) and a backward page (specified with `last`) are requested simultaneously.

args.name: after
args.description:
The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items.
If not specified it's assumed as the cursor for the item before the beginning.

args.name: before
args.description:
The index based cursor to specify the bottom limit of the items.
If not specified it's assumed as the cursor to the item after the last item.

args.name: first
args.description:
The number of items after the cursor to be returned in a forward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

args.name: last
args.description:
The number of items before the cursor to be returned in a backward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

args.name: last
args.description:
The number of items before the cursor to be returned in a backward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

types.name: JiraJqlBuilder
types.description:
Encapsulates queries and fields necessary to power the JQL builder.

It also exposes generic JQL capabilities that can be leveraged to power other experiences.

fields.name: cascadingSelectOptions
fields.description: Retrieves the field-values for the Jira cascading options field.

args.name: after
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor for the item before the beginning.

args.name: before
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the bottom limit of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor to the item after the last item.

args.name: filter
args.description: Only the cascading options matching this filter will be retrieved.

args.name: first
args.description: The number of items to be sliced away to target between the after and before cursors.

args.name: jqlContext
args.description:
The JQL query that will be parsed and used to form a search context.

Only the Jira fields that are scoped to this search context will be returned.

E.g. `Project IN (KEY1, KEY2) AND issueType = Task`

args.name: jqlTerm
args.description:
An identifier that a client should use in a JQL query when it’s referring to an instance of a Jira cascading option field.

Important note: this jqlTerm could require proper escaping before placing it  into a query (e.g. wrap it in "" ).

args.name: last
args.description: The number of items to be sliced away from the bottom of the list after slicing with `first` argument.

args.name: searchString
args.description: Only the Jira field-values with their diplayName matching this searchString will be retrieved.

fields.name: fieldValues
fields.description:
Retrieves a connection of field-values for a specified Jira Field.

E.g. A given Jira checkbox field may have the following field-values: `Option 1`, `Option 2` and `Option 3`.

args.name: after
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items, if not specified the cursor is assumed to be the beginning.

args.name: first
args.description: The number of items after the cursor to be returned, if not specified it is up to the server to determine a page size.

args.name: jqlContext
args.description:
The JQL query that will be parsed and used to form a search context.

Only the Jira fields that are scoped to this search context will be returned.

E.g. `Project IN (KEY1, KEY2) AND issueType = Task`

args.name: jqlTerm
args.description:
An identifier that a client should use in a JQL query when it’s referring to a field-value.

Important note: this jqlTerm could require proper escaping before placing it  into a query (e.g. wrap it in "" ).

args.name: searchString
args.description: Only the Jira field-values with their diplayName matching this searchString will be retrieved.

fields.name: fields
fields.description:
Retrieves a connection of searchable Jira JQL fields.

In a given JQL, fields will precede operators and operators precede field-values/ functions.

E.g. `${FIELD} ${OPERATOR} ${FUNCTION}()` => `Assignee = currentUser()`

args.name: after
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items, if not specified the cursor is assumed to be the beginning.

args.name: first
args.description: The number of items after the cursor to be returned, if not specified it is up to the server to determine a page size.

args.name: forClause
args.description: Only the fields that support the provided JqlClauseType will be returned.

args.name: jqlContext
args.description:
The JQL query that will be parsed and used to form a search context.

Only the Jira fields that are scoped to this search context will be returned.

E.g. `Project IN (KEY1, KEY2) AND issueType = Task`.

args.description: Only the fields that contain this searchString in their displayName will be returned.

fields.name: functions

fields.name: hydrateJqlQuery
fields.description: Hydrates the JQL fields and field-values of a given JQL query.

fields.name: hydrateJqlQueryForFilter
fields.description:
Hydrates the JQL fields and field-values of a filter corresponding to the provided filter ID.

The id provided MUST be in ARI format.

This query will error if the id parameter is not in ARI format, does not pass validation or does not correspond to a JiraFilter.

types.description: An input filter used to specify the cascading options returned.

inputFields.description: The type of cascading option to be returned.

inputFields.name: parentOptionName
inputFields.description:
Used for retrieving CHILD cascading options by specifying the PARENT cascading option's name.

The parent name is case-sensitive and it will not be applied to non-child cascading options.

types.name: JiraCascadingSelectOptionType
types.description:
Cascading options can either be a parent or a child - this enum captures this characteristic.

E.g. If there is a parent cascading option named `P1`, it may or may not have
child cascading options named `C1` and `C2`.
- `P1` would be a `PARENT` enum
- `C1` and `C2` would be `CHILD` enums

enumValues.name: ALL
enumValues.description: All options, regardless of whether they're a parent or child.

enumValues.name: CHILD
enumValues.description: Child option only

enumValues.name: PARENT
enumValues.description: Parent option only

types.description:
The autocomplete types available for Jira fields in the context of the Jira Query Language.

This enum also describes which fields have field-value support from this schema.

enumValues.description: The Jira component field JQL autocomplete type.

enumValues.description: No autocomplete support.

enumValues.name: PRIORITY
enumValues.description: The Jira priority field JQL autocomplete type.

enumValues.name: PROJECT
enumValues.description: The Jira project field JQL autocomplete type.

enumValues.name: STATUS

fields.name: displayName

fields.name: jqlTerm
fields.description: The non-translated name of the field type.

types.name: JiraJqlOperator
types.description:
The types of JQL operators supported by Jira.

An operator in JQL is one or more symbols or words,which compares the value of a field on its left with one or more values (or functions) on its right,
such that only true results are retrieved by the clause.

For more information on JQL operators please visit: https://support.atlassian.com/jira-software-cloud/docs/advanced-search-reference-jql-operators.

enumValues.name: CHANGED
enumValues.description: The `CHANGED` operator is used to find issues that have a value that had changed for the specified field.

enumValues.name: CONTAINS
enumValues.description: The `CHANGED` operator is used to find issues that have a value that had changed for the specified field.

enumValues.name: EQUALS
enumValues.description: The `=` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field exactly matches the specified value.

enumValues.name: GREATER_THAN
enumValues.description: The `>` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field is greater than the specified value.

enumValues.name: GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL
enumValues.description: The `>=` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field is greater than or equal to the specified value.

enumValues.name: IN
enumValues.description: The `IN` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field is one of multiple specified values.

enumValues.name: IS
enumValues.description: The `IS` operator can only be used with EMPTY or NULL. That is, it is used to search for issues where the specified field has no value.

enumValues.name: IS_NOT
enumValues.description: The `IS NOT` operator can only be used with EMPTY or NULL. That is, it is used to search for issues where the specified field has a value.

enumValues.name: LESS_THAN
enumValues.description: The `<` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field is less than the specified value.

enumValues.name: LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL
enumValues.description: The `<=` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field is less than or equal to than the specified value.

enumValues.name: NOT_CONTAINS
enumValues.description: The `!~` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field is not a "fuzzy" match for the specified value.

enumValues.name: NOT_EQUALS
enumValues.description: The `!=` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field does not match the specified value.

enumValues.name: NOT_IN
enumValues.description: The `NOT IN` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field is not one of multiple specified values.

enumValues.name: WAS
enumValues.description: The `WAS` operator is used to find issues that currently have or previously had the specified value for the specified field.

enumValues.name: WAS_IN
enumValues.description: The `WAS IN` operator is used to find issues that currently have or previously had any of multiple specified values for the specified field.

enumValues.name: WAS_NOT
enumValues.description: The `WAS NOT` operator is used to find issues that have never had the specified value for the specified field.

enumValues.name: WAS_NOT_IN
enumValues.description: The `WAS NOT IN` operator is used to search for issues where the value of the specified field has never been one of multiple specified values.

types.name: JiraJqlSearchTemplate
types.description: The representation of a Jira field in the basic search mode of the JQL builder.

types.name: JiraJqlFunction
types.description:
A function in JQL appears as a word followed by parentheses, which may contain one or more explicit values or Jira fields.

In a clause, a function is preceded by an operator, which in turn is preceded by a field.

A function performs a calculation on either specific Jira data or the function's content in parentheses,
such that only true results are retrieved by the function, and then again by the clause in which the function is used.

E.g. `approved()`, `currentUser()`, `endOfMonth()` etc.

fields.name: dataTypes
fields.description:
The data types that this function handles and creates values for.

This allows consumers to infer information on the JiraJqlField type such as which functions are supported.

fields.name: displayName
fields.description: The user-friendly name for the function, to be displayed in the UI.

fields.name: isList
fields.description:
Indicates whether or not the function is meant to be used with IN or NOT IN operators, that is,
if the function should be viewed as returning a list.

The method should return false when it is to be used with the other relational operators (e.g. =, !=, <, >, ...)
that only work with single values.

fields.name: value
fields.description: A JQL-function safe encoded name. This value will not be encoded if the displayName is already safe.

Retrieves top-level issue types that encapsulate all others.

E.g. The `Epic` issue type in company-managed projects.

args.name: before
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the bottom limit of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor to the item after the last item.

args.name: first
args.description: The number of items after the cursor to be returned, if not specified it is up to the server to determine a page size.

args.name: last
args.description: The number of items to be sliced away from the bottom of the list after slicing with `first` argument.

The basic mode, allows queries to be built and executed via the JQL basic editor.

This mode allows users to easily construct JQL queries by interacting with the UI.

This mode allows users to manually type and construct complex JQL queries.

types.name: JiraJqlVersions
types.description:
A variation of the fieldValues query for retrieving specifically Jira version field-values.

This type provides the capability to retrieve connections of released, unreleased and archived versions.

Important note: that released and unreleased versions can be archived and vice versa.

fields.name: archived
fields.description: Retrieves a connection of archived versions.

args.name: after
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor for the item before the beginning.

args.name: before
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the bottom limit of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor to the item after the last item.

args.name: first
args.description: The number of items to be sliced away to target between the after and before cursors.

args.name: last
args.description: The number of items to be sliced away from the bottom of the list after slicing with `first` argument.

fields.name: released
fields.description: Retrieves a connection of released versions.

args.name: after
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor for the item before the beginning.

args.name: before
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the bottom limit of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor to the item after the last item.

args.name: first
args.description: The number of items to be sliced away to target between the after and before cursors.

args.name: includeArchived
args.description: Determines whether or not archived versions are returned. By default it will be false.

args.name: last
args.description: The number of items to be sliced away from the bottom of the list after slicing with `first` argument.

fields.name: unreleased
fields.description: Retrieves a connection of unreleased versions.

args.name: after

args.name: last

types.name: JiraPermissionGrantValue
types.description:
The permission grant value represents the actual permission grant value.
The id field represent the grant ID and its not an ARI. The value represents actual value information specific to grant type.
For example: PROJECT_ROLE grant type value contains project role ID in ARI format and role specific details

fields.name: id
fields.description:
The ID of the permission grant.
It represents the relationship among permission, grant type and grant type specific value.

fields.name: value
fields.description:
The grant type value is an union type.
The value itself may resolve to one of the concrete types such as JiraDefaultGrantTypeValue, JiraProjectRoleGrantTypeValue.

types.name: JiraVersionResult
types.description: Contains either the successful fetched version information or an error.

types.name: JiraVersion
types.description: Jira Version type that can be either Versions system fields or Versions Custom fields.

fields.name: description
fields.description:
Version description.
This is a beta field and has not been implemented yet.

fields.name: iconUrl
fields.description: Version icon URL.

fields.name: name
fields.description: Version name.

fields.name: releaseDate
fields.description:
The date at which the version was released to customers. Must occur after startDate.
This is a beta field and has not been implemented yet.

fields.name: startDate
fields.description:
The date at which work on the version began.
This is a beta field and has not been implemented yet.

fields.name: status
fields.description: Status to which version belongs to.

fields.name: versionId
fields.description: Version Id.

types.name: JiraVersionStatus
types.description: The status of a version field.

enumValues.name: ARCHIVED
enumValues.description: Indicates the version is archived, no further changes can be made to this version unless it is un-archived

enumValues.name: RELEASED
enumValues.description: Indicates the version is available to public

enumValues.name: UNRELEASED
enumValues.description: Indicates the version is not launched yet

types.name: JiraPermissionSchemeViewResult
types.description: The union result representing either the composite view of the permission scheme or the query error information.

types.name: JiraPermissionSchemeView
types.description:
The JiraPermissionSchemeView represents the composite view to capture basic information of
the permission scheme such as id, name, description and a bounded list of one or more grant groups.
A grant group contains existing permission grant information such as permission, permission category, grant type and grant type value.

fields.name: grantGroups
fields.description: The bounded list of one or more grant groups represent each group of permission grants based on project permission category such as PROJECTS, ISSUES.

fields.name: scheme
fields.description: The basic permission scheme information such as id, name and description.

types.name: JiraPermissionSchemeGrantGroup
types.description:
The JiraPermissionSchemeGrantGroup is an association between project permission category information and a bounded list of one or more
associated permission grant holder. A grant holder represents project permission information and its associated permission grants.

fields.name: category
fields.description: The basic project permission category information such as key and display name.

fields.name: grantHolders
fields.description: A bounded list of one or more permission grant holders.

types.name: JiraProjectPermissionCategory
types.description:
The category of the project permission.
The category information is typically seen in the permission scheme Admin UI.
It is used to group the project permissions in general and available for connect app developers when registering new project permissions.

fields.name: key
fields.description: The unique key of the permission category.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The display name of the permission category.

types.name: JiraProjectPermissionCategoryEnum
types.description:
The category of the project permission.
It represents the logical grouping of the project permissions.

enumValues.name: ATTACHMENTS
enumValues.description: Represents one or more permissions to manage issue attacments such as create and delete.

enumValues.name: COMMENTS
enumValues.description: Represents one or more permissions to manage issue comments such as add, delete and edit.

enumValues.name: ISSUES
enumValues.description: Represents one or more permissions applicable at issue level to manage operations such as create, delete, edit, and transition.

enumValues.name: OTHER
enumValues.description: Represents one or more permissions representing default category if not any other existing category.

enumValues.name: PROJECTS
enumValues.description: Represents one or more permissions applicable at project level such as project administration, view project information, and manage sprints.

enumValues.name: TIME_TRACKING
enumValues.description: Represents one or more permissions to manage worklogs, time tracking for billing purpose in some cases.

enumValues.name: VOTERS_AND_WATCHERS
enumValues.description: Represents one or more permissions to manage watchers and voters of an issue.

types.name: JiraPermissionGrantHolder
types.description:
The JiraPermissionGrantHolder represents an association between project permission information and
a bounded list of one or more permission grant.
A permission grant holds association between grant type and a paginated list of grant values.

fields.name: grants
fields.description: A bounded list of jira permission grant.

fields.name: permission
fields.description: The basic information about the project permission.

types.name: JiraPermissionGrants
types.description:
The JiraPermissionGrants represents an association between grant type information and a bounded list of one or more grant
values associated with given grant type.
Each grant value has grant type specific information.
For example, PROJECT_ROLE grant type value contains project role ID in ARI format and role specific details.

fields.name: grantType
fields.description: The grant type information includes key and display name.

fields.name: grantValues
fields.description: A bounded list of grant values. Each grant value has grant type specific information.

types.name: JiraProjectPermission
types.description: The project permission in Jira and it is scoped to projects.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the permission.

fields.name: key
fields.description: The unique key of the permission.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The display name of the permission.

fields.name: type
fields.description: The category of the permission.

types.name: JiraPermissionScheme
types.description: A permission scheme is a collection of permission grants.

fields.name: description
fields.description: The description of the permission scheme.

fields.name: id
fields.description: The ARI of the permission scheme.

fields.name: name
fields.description: The display name of the permission scheme.

fields.name: deployments
fields.description: Deployment summaries that are ordered by the date at which they occured (most recent to least recent).

fields.name: deploymentsById
fields.description:
Query deployment summaries by ID.

A maximum of 100 `deploymentIds` can be asked for at the one time.

fields.name: epics
fields.description:
Epic data that is filtered & ordered based on release-specific information.

The returned epics will be ordered by the dates of the most recent deployments for
the issues within the epic that match the input filter. An epic containing an issue
that was released more recently will appear earlier in the list.

fields.name: issues
fields.description:
Issue data that is filtered & ordered based on release-specific information.

The returned issues will be ordered by the dates of the most recent deployments that
match the input filter. An issue that was released more recently will appear earlier
in the list.

inputFields.name: environmentCategories
inputFields.description: Only deployments in these environment types will be returned.

inputFields.name: environmentDisplayNames
inputFields.description: Only deployments in these environments will be returned.

inputFields.name: issueIds
inputFields.description: Only deployments associated with these issues will be returned.

inputFields.name: serviceIds
inputFields.description: Only deployments associated with these services will be returned.

inputFields.name: timeWindow
inputFields.description: Only deployments in this time window will be returned.

inputFields.name: projectId
inputFields.description: Only epics in this project will be returned.

inputFields.name: releaseStatusFilter
inputFields.description: Determines whether epics that haven't been released should be included in the results.

inputFields.name: text
inputFields.description: Only epics matching this text filter will be returned.

types.name: JiraReleasesEpicReleaseStatusFilter
types.description:
Used for specifying whether or not epics that haven't been released should be included
in the results.

For an epic to be considered as released, at least one of the issues or subtasks within
it must have been released.

enumValues.name: RELEASED
enumValues.description: Only epics that have been released (to any environment) will be included in the results.

enumValues.name: RELEASED_AND_UNRELEASED
enumValues.description:
Epics that have been released will be returned first, followed by epics that haven't
yet been released.

inputFields.name: assignees
inputFields.description: Only issues assigned to these users will be returned.

inputFields.name: environmentCategories
inputFields.description: Only issues that have been released in these environment *types* will be returned.

inputFields.name: environmentDisplayNames
inputFields.description: Only issues that have been released in these environments will be returned.

inputFields.name: epicIds
inputFields.description:
Only issues in these epics will be returned.

Note:
* If a null ID is included in the list, issues not in epics will be included in the results.
* If a subtask's parent issue is in one of the epics, the subtask will also be returned.

inputFields.name: fixVersions
inputFields.description: Only issues with the supplied fixVersions will be returned.

inputFields.name: issueTypes
inputFields.description: Only issues of these types will be returned.

inputFields.name: projectId
inputFields.description: Only issues in this project will be returned.

inputFields.name: releaseStatusFilter
inputFields.description: Determines whether issues that haven't been released should be included in the results.

inputFields.name: text
inputFields.description: Only issues matching this text filter will be returned (will match against all issue fields).

inputFields.name: timeWindow
inputFields.description:
Only issues that have been released within this time window will be returned.

Note: Issues that have not been released within the time window will still be returned
if the `includeIssuesWithoutReleases` argument is `true`.

types.name: JiraReleasesIssueReleaseStatusFilter
types.description:
Used for specifying whether or not issues that haven't been released should be included
in the results.

enumValues.name: RELEASED
enumValues.description: Only issues that have been released (to any environment) will be included in the results.

enumValues.name: RELEASED_AND_UNRELEASED
enumValues.description:
Issues that have been released will be returned first, followed by issues that haven't
yet been released.

enumValues.name: UNRELEASED
enumValues.description: Only issues that have *not* been released (to any environment) will be included in the results.

fields.name: epic
fields.description:
The epic this issue is contained within (either directly or indirectly).

Note: If the issue and its ancestors are not within an epic, the value will be `null`.

types.name: MarketplacePricingPlanOptions
types.description: Option parameters to fetch pricing plan for a marketplace entity

inputFields.name: billingCycle
inputFields.description: Period for which Pricing Plan is to be fetched. Defaults to MONTHLY

inputFields.name: countryCode
inputFields.description: Country code (ISO 3166-1 alpha-2) of the client. Either of currencyCode and countryCode is needed. If both are not present, fallback to default currency - USD

inputFields.name: currencyCode

An PolarisIdeaField is a unit of information that can be instantiated

fields.name: builtin
fields.description:
An identifier for fields built in to Jira or Polaris.  For example, "Key" and
"Delivery progress" are builtin fields.

fields.name: decorations
fields.description:
Values stored in this field can be decorated with visual elements
(emojis, colors, backgrounds) for distinction. For discrete types
such as Single/Multi select these will typically be exact matches
on the static values allowed by the field. For orderable types
such as strings, dates, numbers, etc decorations will more
commonly be applied using ranges.

fields.name: defaultSortOrder
fields.description:
What is the default sort order?  This is the order you get on
"first click" of the column, and also the semantics of "ORDER BY"
without an ASC or DESC qualifier.

fields.name: description
fields.description: Description

fields.name: editable
fields.description:
Are values in this field directly editable?  Some integrations
might bring in data that is not directly editable.

fields.name: fieldId
fields.description:
A short identifier suitable for at least within this project,
but only supplied for fields that are returned via an PolarisIdea's fields
attribute.  If not present, this field represents a builtin field
on PolarisIdea.


This field is **deprecated** and will be removed in the future

fields.name: fieldName
fields.description:
The name of the field built in to PolarisIdea, if this field represents
a builtin field.


This field is **deprecated** and will be removed in the future

fields.name: formula
fields.description: The formula for calculated fields; null for regular (stored) fields

fields.name: groupable
fields.description:
Is this field suitable for grouping operations like Board view?
(i.e., may it appear in the groupBy field in a view?)

fields.name: id
fields.description: The fully qualified globally unique id (ARI) for this field

fields.name: jiraFieldKey
fields.description:
The key of this field in the `fields` structure if it is a Jira
field.  Not set for things that don't appear in the fields section
of a Jira issue object, such as "key"

fields.name: linearizable
fields.description:
Is this field suitable for linear operations like plotting on an axis?
(i.e., may it appear in the x or y field in a view?)

fields.name: presentation
fields.description:
Refines how we should present the field.  For example, a number
field might be presented with a Rating picker.

fields.name: sortable
fields.description:
Can rows be sorted by this field?  Some fields are not commensurate
and hence can't be sorted.

args.name: filters

This object determines the tenants/locations where the search should be performed.
It also determines the kind of results which must be returned.

As this supports multiple products and each products have different set of filters.
The implementation is split by the product.

fields.name: commentsByAri

Get comments by ARI.

### Beta Field

This field is currently in a beta phase and may change without notice.  

To use this field you must set a `X-ExperimentalApi: Townsquare` HTTP header.

Use of this header indicates that they are opting into the experimental preview of this field.

If you do not set this header then request will be rejected outright.

Once the field moves out of the beta phase, then the header will no longer be required or checked.

fields.name: createApp
fields.description: Creates an application in Xen

fields.name: createAppTunnels
fields.description:
Create multiple tunnels for an app

This will allow api calls for this app to be tunnelled to a locally running
server to help with writing and debugging functions.

This call covers both the FaaS tunnel as well as registering multiple Custom UI tunnels
that can then be used in the products instead of serving the usual CDN url.

This call will fail if a tunnel already exists, unless the 'force' flag is set.

Tunnels automatically expire after 30 minutes

fields.name: createDevOpsService
fields.description: Create a DevOps Service

fields.name: createDevOpsServiceAndJiraProjectRelationship
fields.description: Creates a relationships between a DevOps Service and a Jira project

fields.name: createDevOpsServiceAndOpsgenieTeamRelationship
fields.description:
Create a relationship between a DevOps Service and an Opsgenie team.

A DevOps Service can be related to no more than one team. If you attempt to relate more than one team
with a DevOps Service, this mutation will fail with a SERVICE_AND_OPSGENIE_TEAM_RELATIONSHIP_TOO_MANY_TEAMS error.

A team can be related to no more than 1,000 DevOps Services. If you attempt to relate too many services
with a team, this mutation will fail with a SERVICE_AND_OPSGENIE_TEAM_RELATIONSHIP_TOO_MANY_SERVICES error.

fields.name: createDevOpsServiceAndRepositoryRelationship
fields.description:
Create a relationship between a DevOps Service and a Repository.

A single service may be associated with at most 300 repositories. If too many repositories are associated with a
DevOps Service, this mutation will fail with a SERVICE_AND_REPOSITORY_RELATIONSHIP_TOO_MANY_REPOSITORIES error.

A single Repository may be associated with at most 300 DevOps Services. If too many DevOps Services are associated with a
Repository, this mutation will fail with a SERVICE_AND_REPOSITORY_RELATIONSHIP_TOO_MANY_SERVICES error.

fields.name: createDevOpsServiceRelationship
fields.description: Create a DevOps Service Relationship

fields.name: createJiraProjectAndOpsgenieTeamRelationship
fields.description: Create a relationship between a Jira project and an Opsgenie team.

fields.name: createJiraProjectAndRepositoryRelationship
fields.description:
Create a relationship between a Jira project and a repository.

A single Jira project may be associated with at most 100 repositories. If too many repositories are associated with a
Jira project, this mutation will fail with a TOO_MANY_EXPLICIT_REPOSITORY_RELATIONSHIPS_FOR_PROJECT error.

A single Repository may be associated with at most 100 Jira projects. If too many Jira projects are associated with a
repository, this mutation will fail with a TOO_MANY_EXPLICIT_PROJECT_RELATIONSHIPS_FOR_REPOSITORY error.

types.name: CreateAppTunnelsInput
types.description:
Establish tunnels for a specific environment of an app.

This will redirect all function calls to the provided faas url. This URL must implement the same
invocation contract that is used elsewhere in Xen.

This will also be used to redirect Custom UI product rendering to the custom ui urls. We separate
them by extension key.

inputFields.name: appId
inputFields.description: The app to setup a tunnel for

inputFields.name: environmentKey
inputFields.description: The environment key

inputFields.name: force
inputFields.description: Should existing tunnels be overwritten

inputFields.name: tunnelDefinitions
inputFields.description: The tunnel definitions

inputFields.name: faasTunnelUrl
inputFields.description: The URL to tunnel FaaS calls to

types.name: CreateAppTunnelResponse
types.description: A response to a tunnel creation request

fields.name: expiry
fields.description:
The actual expiry time (in milliseconds) of the created forge tunnel. Once the
tunnel expires, Forge apps will display the deployed version even
if the local development server is still active.

fields.name: keepAlive
fields.description:
The recommended keep-alive time (in milliseconds) by which the forge CLI (or
other clients) should re-establish the forge tunnel.
This is guaranteed to be less than the expiry of the forge tunnel.

fields.name: addPermissionSchemeGrants
fields.description:
The mutation operation to add one or more new permission grants to the given permission scheme.
The operation takes mandatory permission scheme ID.
The limit on the new permission grants can be added is set to 5.

### Beta Field

This field is currently in a beta phase and may change without notice.  

To use this field you must set a `X-ExperimentalApi: PermissionScheme` HTTP header.

Use of this header indicates that they are opting into the experimental preview of this field.

If you do not set this header then request will be rejected outright.

Once the field moves out of the beta phase, then the header will no longer be required or checked.

Use of this header indicates that they are opting into the experimental preview of this field.

If you do not set this header then request will be rejected outright.

Once the field moves out of the beta phase, then the header will no longer be required or checked.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields` and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

inputFields.description:
The column to insert this column before.  If not specified,
the new column is added to the right of all columns.

inputFields.name: format

the field label should be used.

args.name: after
args.description:
The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items.
If not specified it's assumed as the cursor for the item before the beginning.

args.name: before
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the bottom limit of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor to the item after the last item.

args.name: first
args.description:
The number of items after the cursor to be returned in a forward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

args.name: last
args.description:
The number of items before the cursor to be returned in a backward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

types.name: JiraCascadingOption
types.description:
Represents the pair of values (parent & child combination) in a cascading select.
This type is used to represent a selected cascading field value on a Jira Issue.
Since this is 2 level hierarchy, it is not possible to represent the same underlying
type for both single cascadingOption and list of cascadingOptions. Thus, we have created different types.

fields.name: childOptionValue
fields.description: Defines the selected single child option value for the parent.

fields.name: parentOptionValue
fields.description: Defines the parent option value.

types.name: JiraOption
types.description: Represents a single option value in a select operation.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Global Identifier of the option.

fields.name: isDisabled
fields.description: Whether or not the option has been disabled by the user. Disabled options are typically not accessible in the UI.

fields.name: optionId
fields.description: Identifier of the option.

fields.name: value
fields.description: Value of the option.

types.name: JiraCascadingOptions
types.description: Represents the childs options allowed values for a parent option in cascading select operation.

fields.name: childOptionValues
fields.description: Defines all the list of child options available for the parent option.

fields.name: parentOptionValue
fields.description: Defines the parent option value.

args.name: after
args.description:
The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items.
If not specified it's assumed as the cursor for the item before the beginning.

args.name: before
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the bottom limit of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor to the item after the last item.

args.name: first
args.description:
The number of items after the cursor to be returned in a forward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

args.name: last
args.description:
The number of items before the cursor to be returned in a backward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

types.name: JiraIssueLink
types.description:
Represents a single issue link containing the link id, link type and destination issue.

For issue create, JiraIssueLink will be populated with
the default IssueLink types in the relatedBy field.
The issueLinkId and issue fields will be null.

For issue view, JiraIssueLink will be populated with
the issue link data available on the issue.
The issue field will contain a nested JiraIssue that is atmost 1 level deep.
The nested JiraIssue will not contain fields that can contain further nesting.

fields.name: id
fields.description: Global identifier for the Issue Link.

fields.name: issue
fields.description: The destination Issue to which this link is connected.

fields.name: issueLinkId
fields.description: Identifier for the Issue Link. Can be null to represent a link not yet created

fields.name: relatedBy
fields.description:
Issue link type relation through which the source issue is connected to the
destination issue. Source Issue is the Issue being created/queried.

fields.name: direction
fields.description: Represents the direction of issue link type. E.g. INWARD, OUTWARD

fields.name: id
fields.description: Global identifier for the Issue Link Type Relation.

fields.name: linkTypeId
fields.description: Represents the IssueLinkType id to which this type belongs to.

fields.name: linkTypeName
fields.description: Display name of IssueLinkType to which this relation belongs to. E.g. Blocks, Duplicate, Cloners

fields.name: relationName
fields.description:
Represents the description of the relation by which this link is identified.
This can be the inward or outward description of an IssueLinkType.
E.g. blocks, is blocked by, duplicates, is duplicated by, clones, is cloned by.

types.name: JiraIssueLinkDirection
types.description: Represents the possible linking directions between issues.

enumValues.name: INWARD
enumValues.description: Going from the other issue to this issue.

enumValues.name: OUTWARD
enumValues.description: Going from this issue to the other issue.

types.name: JiraServiceManagementPractice
types.description: ITSM project practice categorization.

enumValues.name: CHANGE_MANAGEMENT
enumValues.description: Empower the IT operations teams with richer contextual information around changes from software development tools so they can make better decisions and minimize risk.

enumValues.name: INCIDENT_MANAGEMENT
enumValues.description: Bring the development and IT operations teams together to rapidly respond to, resolve, and continuously learn from incidents.

enumValues.name: PROBLEM_MANAGEMENT
enumValues.description: Group incidents to problems, fast-track root cause analysis, and record workarounds to minimize the impact of incidents.

enumValues.name: SERVICE_REQUEST
enumValues.description: Manage work across teams with one platform so the employees and customers quickly get the help they need.

args.name: after
args.description:
The index based cursor to specify the beginning of the items.
If not specified it's assumed as the cursor for the item before the beginning.

args.name: before
args.description: The index based cursor to specify the bottom limit of the items, if not specified it's assumed as the cursor to the item after the last item.

args.name: first
args.description:
The number of items after the cursor to be returned in a forward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

args.name: last
args.description:
The number of items before the cursor to be returned in a backward page.
If not specified, it is up to the server to determine a page size.

types.name: _AppliedDirective
types.description: An Applied Directive is an instances of a directive as applied to a schema element. This type is NOT specified by the graphql specification presently.

types.name: _DirectiveArgument
types.description: Directive arguments can have names and values.  The values are in graphql SDL syntax printed as a string. This type is NOT specified by the graphql specification presently.

types.name: SearchConfluencePageBlogAttachment
types.description:
Add only product specific properties below. Generic properties must be in the SearchResult

CONFLUENCE

directives.name: beta
directives.description:
This directive can be placed on fields so that consumers need to opt in to using them
via a HTTP header.

See https://developer.atlassian.com/platform/graphql-gateway/ for more details

directives.name: value
directives.description:
This directive allows an alternate string value to be associated with an enum.  For example
`manage:org` is the name of a scope but an illegal graphql enum name.  This allows you to use
enums (which are type safe) yet associate them with string values that are needed

directives.name: apiGroup
directives.description:
This directive can be applied to a schema element to indicate that it belongds to a particular api group

This is used by our documentation tooling to group together types and fields into logical groups

directives.name: namespaced
directives.description:
This directive can be applied to a top level field to indicate that it is indeed a namespace field, that is
its not a field that returns data but there to contain other fields that return data.

This is used by our documentation tooling to help present the most important fields.

directives.name: notDocumented
directives.description: This rarely used directive can be used on an schema element to tell the tooling to NOT document the element

directives.name: scopes
directives.description:
This directive will ensure that the data for the annotated element is returned to the 3rd party only when the required
scopes are present in the user context token (scope check). When the product argument is supplied, in addition to the
scopes being present, it is also required that the scopes have been consented to for that product on the site where the
data is queried from (grant check). When data is not queried from a site, grant check is ignored.
If either the scope check or the grant check fails, the returned field will be null and a corresponding error is going to
be added to the list of errors.
This directive is ignored for the 1st party requests.

directives.name: skip
directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Skipped when true.

directives.name: include
directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Included when true.

directives.name: deprecated
directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.

args.name: reason
args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted using the Markdown syntax (as specified by [CommonMark](https://commonmark.org/).
